primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to major themes in the development of Greek and Roman civilization, literature and culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Classical Studies

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: The study of technical and scientific terms derived from Latin and Greek: word elements, formation, analysis. The course is designed to give students in any field of specialization a better grasp of the derivation and basic meaning of English words derived from Latin and Greek elements.
cmCourseInfo.title: Latin & Greek in Scientific Terminology

courses.name: Latin and Greek in Scientific Terminology

cmCourseInfo.description: The study of technical and scientific terms derived from Latin and Greek: word elements, formation, analysis. The course is designed to give students in any field of specialization a better grasp of the derivation and basic meaning of English words formed from Latin and Greek elements.
cmCourseInfo.title: Latin and Greek in Scientific Terminology

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the myths and legends of ancient Greece (and their extension to Rome) with some consideration of their role in ancient and modern literature and art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Classical Mythology

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the myths and legends of ancient Greece (and their extension to Rome) with some consideration of their role in ancient and modern literature and art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Classical Mythology

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the myths and legends of the ancient Greek and Roman Mediterranean world in ancient art and literature. Consideration may also be given to their reception in modern art and literature and some modern theories of myth.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Classical Mythology

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: A historical survey of the most significant features in the development of the civilization and state of ancient Rome from the mythical beginnings to the fourth century C.E.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Roman History

cmCourseInfo.description: A general introduction to early technology, its achievements and limitations, the origins and development of ancient science, including ancient medicine, and their interaction with philosophy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ancient Science and Technology

courses.name: Sexuality and Gender in Classical Literature

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Detailed study of the representation of sexuality and gender in Greek and/or Roman literary texts from one or more genres.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sexuality and Gender in Classical Literature
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: CLA160H1/ CLA170H1, CLA219H1/ CLA222H1/ CLA223H1/ CLA224H1/ CLA232H1/ CLA233H1/ CLA260H1

cmCourseInfo.description: Independent Studies. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Student-initiated project of reading and research, supervised by a member of the Department. Primarily intended for students in a Major program. After obtaining a supervisor, a student must apply to the Department of Historical Studies. A maximum of 1.0 credit in a reading course is permitted.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Reading

cmCourseInfo.description: Student-initiated project of reading and research, supervised by a member of the Department. Primarily intended for Majors. After obtaining a supervisor, a student must apply to the Department of Historical Studies. A maximum of two reading courses, amounting to 1.0 credit, is permitted.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Reading
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least 2.5 credits in Classics, including at least 1.5 credits at the 300 level.

cmCourseInfo.description: Student-initiated project of reading and research, supervised by a member of the Department. Primarily intended for Majors. After obtaining a supervisor, a student must apply to the Department of Historical Studies. A maximum of two reading courses, amounting to 1.0 credit, is permitted.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Reading
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least 2.5 credits in Classics, including at least 1.5 credits at the 300 level.

courses.name: Ancient Mythology I: Mesopotamia and Egypt

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of Mesopotamian and Egyptian mythologies. Special attention will be dedicated to the sources through which these representational patterns are documented and to their influence on Mediterranean civilizations and arts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ancient Mythology I: Mesopotamia and Egypt
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: CLAA05H3 may not be taken after or concurrently with NMC380Y

courses.name: History and Culture of the Roman World

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the history and culture of the ancient Roman world, from the Etruscan period to the Justinian dynasty (ca 800 BC-600 AD). Special attention will be dedicated to the nature, variety and limits of the available evidences, to socio-cultural interactions as well as to historical processes of continuities and ruptures. Same as HISB11H3
cmCourseInfo.title: History and Culture of the Roman World
